data.speaker: Douglas Crockford
data.detail:
The web was originally imagined to be a simple distributed document retrieval system. It is now being used for applications that go far beyond the system's original capabilities and intentions. We have found ways to make it work, but they are difficult and far too fragile. Many times companies have offered to replace the web with superior proprietary systems, but we rejected them. We have been adding features to the web, but this does little to correct the deep underlying deficiencies, increasing instead of reducing its complexity.

This talk suggests a way forward, taking inspiration from our successful transition from NTSC to HDTV. There is a way forward to a web that is safer, easier, and as good as we desire.

data.session: Rapid Digital Innovation - How NodeJS Delivers
data.speaker: Richard Rodger
data.speakerTitle: Author of Beginning Mobile Application Development in the Cloud
data.detail: Ongoing digital innovation has become vital to delivering enterprise goals. With the requirement to delivery technology solutions ever faster, traditional architectures and platforms are struggling to keep pace.

data.speaker: Apoorv Saxena
data.detail: Performance is a Feature, the janky your website displays, the lesser will be the user interaction and conversions, thereby impacting the growth and revenue of your business. Yet many people are not able to understand the performance gotchas completely, and don’t make it a part of their deployment process to measure the rendering performance of their webpages. In this workshop, participants will Performance Audit Web Applications to make them run them at 60fps. Workshop will consist of: Understand the working behind several jQuery functions and their performance impacts. Profiling with Dev Tools available in Browsers, to explore the rendering issues and their respective remedies. Discussion of case studies of already audited web applications, and discuss their performance remedies as well. Live Audit of Web applications by Workshop attendees.

data.session: WebGL And ThreeJS - Utilising the next generation of powerful graphics API's on the web
data.speaker: Joe Pettersson
data.detail: The WebGL API open's up an exciting world of possibilities for the web; allowing us to build complex applications, games and experiences that were never possible before. In this workshop we'll learn how to leverage WebGL directly, and also how to utilise it through one of it's most useful abstraction layers: ThreeJS. We'll cover the basics of rendering scenes and objects with lighting, textures and cameras; as well as interacting with them using directly and indirectly through the use of physics engines. You should come away from this talk with a thirst to learn more about this powerful technology, as well as a basic foundation of skills and knowledge to assist you in that exploration in building your own applications and games. In order to take the most from this talk, you should have a good understanding of browser JavaScript API's (the DOM API et al) as well as the heart not to be discouraged when we occasionally use phrases like 'matrix manipulation' and 'vector transforms'.

data.session: Building A Mini Angular Framework From The Ground Up
data.speaker: Magesh K
data.detail:
1. Understanding when HTML5/JS is Appropriate for Gaming and When it's Not
    1. Pros of HTML5 Gaming
    2. Cons of HTML5 Gaming
    3. Cross Device Alternatives
      1. Unity Engine
      2. Native Porting
      3. WebGL
  2. HTML5 Game Architecture
    1. Loading/Preloading Assets
    2. Asset Hierarchies
    3. Server Interaction
    4. Game Loop
    5. Libraries
  3. Developing the App
    1. Creating the Application Shell
    2. Including Necessary Libraries
    3. Coding the Basic Game Loop
    4. Adding Player Interaction
    5. Adding Animations
    6. Adding Sounds
    7. Adding Scoring
    8. Making the Game Replayable
  4. Testing Across Environments
  5. Release Considerations

data.speaker: Yehuda Katz
data.speakerTitle: Open Source Evagelist, Co-founder Tilde Inc.

data.speaker: Adriaan de Jonge
data.detail: The new direction Angular 2.0 is taking created a lot of discussion in the community. Some people love it, some people hate it. Most people agree there is room for simplification, performance enhancements and native support of new language features. Not everyone likes the way Angular 2.0 is picking these up though. There is an alternative direction: Aurelia. In this talk, we'll do a side-by-side comparison and have the audience answer the question: Should you keep all your eggs in the Angular basket?

data.speaker: HariKrishnan and Dharampal
data.speakerTitle: Developers AT MavenHive Technologies Pvt. Ltd.
data.detail: The design of Languages and Frameworks is highly influenced by the context and their history. As a developer it is important to be aware of these evolutionary aspects which have led to the current feature set of JS and its Frameworks. More over JS has a very interesting history.

data.session: React & Flux - Learn When & How to Leverage the Power of Virtual DOM & Reactive Data Flows
data.speaker: Christian Lilley
data.speakerTitle: UI Architect at McKinsey Digital Labs
data.detail:
Whatever other tools you use and love, one thing about ReactJS is certain: the 'Virtual DOM' approach is the future of the web. It's just too fast and too sensible to ignore. In this session, we'll learn:

  1. What 'Virtual DOM' is and why it matters
  2. How you can begin making use of it now, in your existing environments
  3. How React also thinks differently about data-binding, with its 'one-way reactive data flow'

Longer-Term, React combined with the 'Flux' pattern points the way to a very different style of front-end application development than we're used to now: very modular, 'component'-driven architectures. At the same time, one of the signal traits of React/Flux is that more and more of the application is contained exclusively in Javascript files: React's HTML elements are declared as either 'JSX' templates, or just as Javascript objects. And some folks are taking this on to the next level, even programming all of their CSS in JS as well! Before this session is over, you'll see how all these pieces fit together and how you can build some very effective, very fast, and very maintainable components and apps this way. That said, we'll also discuss what's still missing from the React/Flux ecosystem, and provide you with a roadmap that allows you decide when you can - and when you can't - build your whole application around it.

data.speaker: David Hoffer
data.speakerTitle: Design Director at McKinsey Digital Labs
data.detail: In this workshop, David Hoffer will be present a Design Thinking lecture and hands-on exercises to help you better understand Design Thinking and it's implications for your work with a specific focus on Personas and Customer Journey Mapping. Please join us for fun and informative session.

data.speaker: Douglas, Yehuda and other speakers
data.speakerTitle: With Douglas, Yehuda and other speakers
data.detail: Attendees have full 60 mins with the speakers. Its your time to ask any question to Douglas, Yehuda and other speakers.

data.speaker: Satty Bhens
data.speakerTitle: Digital Principal at McKinsey Digital Labs

overview.subtitle: WE, THE JAVASCRIPT PEOPLE
overview.description: Join us at the JS Channel Conference in Bengaluru for an oppurtunity to learn and hear from the best brains in the industry. Two days of hands-on workshops and talks. A great platform to mingle with the community. As always lunch and high tea on us. We look forward to seeing you there and hope you enjoy the mobile app.
overview.feature1: Browse around the app to find the latest agenda, session details, speaker information and venue maps.
overview.feature2: Takes place on July 17-18, 2015, Hotel Taj Vivanta, Bengaluru.
overview.feature3: Contact us at jsconference@gmail.com with any queries or concerns.

speakers.name: Douglas Crockford
speakers.description: Douglas Crockford was born in the Frostbite Falls, Minnesota, but left when he was only six months old because it was just too damn cold. He turned his back on a promising career in television when he discovered computers. He has worked in learning systems, small business systems, office automation, games, interactive music, multimedia, location-based entertainment, social systems, and programming languages. He is the inventor of Tilton, the ugliest programming language that was not specifically designed to be an ugly programming language. He is best known for having discovered that there are good parts in JavaScript. This was an important and unexpected discovery. He also discovered the JSON Data Interchange Format, the world's most loved data format. And he works at Paypal.
speakers.topic_description:
The web was originally imagined to be a simple distributed document retrieval system. It is now being used for applications that go far beyond the system's original capabilities and intentions. We have found ways to make it work, but they are difficult and far too fragile. Many times companies have offered to replace the web with superior proprietary systems, but we rejected them. This talk suggests a way forward, taking inspiration from our successful transition from NTSC to HDTV. There is a way forward to a web that is safer, easier, and as good as we desire.

speakers.name: Richard Rodger
speakers.known_for: Author of Beginning Mobile Application Development in the Cloud
speakers.topic: Rapid Digital Innovation - How NodeJS Delivers
speakers.description: Richard Rodger is the CTO of nearForm.com, a Node.js consultancy that builds large-scale systems. Richard is the author of Mobile Application Development in the Cloud (Wiley 2012), and was formerly CTO of feedhenry.com, a mobile applications platform. He is a regular contributor to the Sunday Business Post newspaper in Ireland, and holds degrees in Mathematics and Philosophy, and Computer Science.
speakers.session: Rapid Digital Innovation - How NodeJS Delivers
speakers.topic_description: The Node.js platform offers a lean, effective, and proven in-production approach that can deliver rapid digital innovation. This talk explores the challenges of large scale enterprise delivery, and the way in which Node.js overcomes these.

speakers.name: Apoorv Saxena
speakers.description: We hate slow and janky websites, every user wants an application to load in less than a second and perform jank-free. PerfAudit is a step towards achieving this goal, by involving the experts and the business owners to find the keyholes hindering the performance of web applications. With every Performance Audit, we not only intend to help make a web application perform fast, but also add our findings to the pool of performance improvements that developers must add into their deployment routine to make evergreen performant applications.
speakers.topic_description: Performance is a Feature, the janky your website displays, the lesser will be the user interaction and conversions, thereby impacting the growth and revenue of your business. Yet many people are not able to understand the performance gotchas completely, and don’t make it a part of their deployment process to measure the rendering performance of their webpages. In this workshop, participants will Performance Audit Web Applications to make them run them at 60fps. Workshop will consist of: Understand the working behind several jQuery functions and their performance impacts. Profiling with Dev Tools available in Browsers, to explore the rendering issues and their respective remedies. Discussion of case studies of already audited web applications, and discuss their performance remedies as well. Live Audit of Web applications by Workshop attendees.

speakers.name: Joe Pettersson
speakers.topic: WebGL And ThreeJS - Utilising the next generation of powerful graphics API's on the web
speakers.description: Joe's UI Engineering Lead at McKinsey & Company, specifially at McKinsey Digital Labs. He's passionate about user-interfaces, user-experiences and building kick-ass tools and products. He's been writing JavaScript since the late 1990's, and has a passion for talking about it publically. He's half Swedish and half English, which means that while he loves herring, snow and flat-pack furniture; he also never performs adequatley at international football tournaments.
speakers.session: WebGL And ThreeJS - Utilising the next generation of powerful graphics API's on the web
speakers.topic_description: The WebGL API open's up an exciting world of possibilities for the web; allowing us to build complex applications, games and experiences that were never possible before. speakers.name: Magesh K
speakers.topic: Building A Mini Angular Framework From The Ground Up
speakers.description: Magesh has a rich 18 years of experience in software development, consulting and training. He combines rich technical knowledge and domain expertise in breadth and depth that helps to create extremely rich and powerful end user experience – be it insightful technical discussions during training or powerful software solutions. He had been working on RIA using JavaScript and built custom MVC frameworks in JavaScript before the arrival of the likes of Backbone.js etc.
speakers.session: Building A Mini Angular Framework From The Ground Up
speakers.topic_description:
This live coding session will reveal the inner secrets of how Angular.js works by attempting re-create a mini angular.js like framework from the ground up. This will help gain better understanding on some of the guiding principles of angular.js.

In this session, the participants will learn
  1. Creating a 'Scope' api for two-way data-binding
  2. Creating a DI container
  3. Create the HTML Compilation process
  4. Create simple directives from the scratch
  5. Bootstrap the application

speakers.name: Yehuda Katz
speakers.known_for: Open Source Evagelist, Co-founder Tilde Inc.
speakers.description: Yehuda Katz is a member of the  Ember.js and Rust Core Teams, and a retired Ruby on Rails and jQuery Core Team member. His 9-to-5 home is at the startup he founded, Tilde Inc.. There he works on Skylight, the smart profiler for Rails, and does Ember.js consulting. He's best known for his open source work, which also includes projects like Thor, Handlebars and Bundler.

speakers.name: Adriaan de Jonge
speakers.description: Adriaan specializes in DevOps and Continuous Delivery - he is co–author of The Manager’s Guide to Continuous Delivery, which was published in 2014. He also wrote two developer guides about web technology, published by Addison–Wesley in 2011 and 2012. Adriaan is a regular speaker at conferences, including PipelineConf London 2014, Jenkins User Group Copenhagen 2014 and DevOps Summit Amsterdam 2014.

Most people agree there is room for simplification, performance enhancements and native support of new language features. Not everyone likes the way Angular 2.0 is picking these up though. There is an alternative direction: Aurelia. In this talk, we'll do a side-by-side comparison and have the audience answer the question: Should you keep all your eggs in the Angular basket?

speakers.name: HariKrishnan and Dharampal
speakers.known_for: Developers AT MavenHive Technologies Pvt. Ltd.
speakers.description: Hari is an Application Developer with a decade of experience across several technology stacks. He has spoken at several technology conferences. His areas of interest include Concurrency and high performance applications.

As a developer it is important to be aware of these evolutionary aspects which have led to the current feature set of JS and its Frameworks. More over JS has a very interesting history.

speakers.name: Christian Lilley
speakers.known_for: UI Architect at McKinsey Digital Labs.
speakers.topic: React & Flux - Learn When & How to Leverage the Power of Virtual DOM & Reactive Data Flows
speakers.description: Christian Lilley turns theoretical business-y stuff into blinky-lights that actually do useful things. He digs rapid-prototyping with AngularJS, speaks often at conferences like ng-conf and CSSConf Asia, and co-founded the Meetup 'Data Visualization NY'. Now he lives in KL, wishing there was a GeoViz that could help him find the best hawker stalls.

speakers.description: David Hoffer is the Experience Design Director for the Design studio in San Francisco. He has specific experience in Design Strategy, Interaction and Visual Design as well as deep expertise in User Research, brand development and Service Design.
